item.title: Report E-2024110454
item.description:
Report E-2024110454

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-25T12:24:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-14
  • City: BIRMINGHAM
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On November 14, 2024, six (6) 2.5-liter jars of hydrochloric acid arrived to the terminal damaged and released approximately 1.25-liters of product to the trailer interior and adjacent cargo. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews deployed a neutralizing agent to the impacted areas. Once neutralization was confirmed with pH strips, absorbent pads were utilized to remove any residual product. The damaged jars, and cardboard box were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal. All spent absorbents, pads and PPE were collected and containerized into one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024110403
item.description:
Report E-2024110403

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-22T12:30:52+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-13
  • City: BIRMINGHAM
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On November 13, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1760 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately three (3) quarts of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Marion Environmental, Inc. (MEI) to remediate the impacted site. MEI personnel deployed granular absorbents to the UN1760-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents as well as the damaged product were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum which was staged onsite for future disposal by CES personnel.
